+ Historical fiction: Gladiator — Score: 85.2
Prompt:
Historical Fiction: Write a scene from a story set during the height of the Roman Empire, focusing on a slice of a day in the life of a gladiator. Do not write a combat scene. Use sensory details to capture the sights, sounds, and smells of ancient Rome. Explore the gladiator's thoughts and emotions. The story should also touch on the larger political and social issues of the time period. The piece should feel like a slice of a larger story. First person, past tense, 1000 words.
Model Output:
The sun had not yet cleared the rooftops when the scent of old blood and sweat found me, seeping through the slats of my cell. Rome herself was waking: I heard her in the shouts of vendors rolling carts past the ludus, the clatter of hooves on paving stones, the distant clang of hammers from the forges. Even in captivity, the city’s pulse was inescapable. I lay on my cot, tracing the rough grain of the wooden handle beside me—my sica, curved and hungry as a crescent moon. They called me “Siro,” though my mother had given me a different name, long ago in Dacia. The sica was a weapon they feared, short and wicked, made for slipping past shields and armor. It was not the blade of a Roman, not an honest gladius or a heavy trident. But it fit my hand. When I gripped it, I remembered the forests of home, the way the moonlight shone on the river’s bend. The Romans had taken everything else; this knife and the memory of my land were all that remained. My cell was little more than a pen—wattle walls, straw bedding, the iron tang of urine and sweat. The other men were stirring. I heard Vibius, the murmillo, scratch at his beard and spit. He was a citizen, condemned for debts, and quick to remind us of the difference. None of us were free, but in chains, even a Roman found something to lord over the rest. A horn sounded in the courtyard, sharp as a slap. We rose, stretching cramped limbs, and filed out beneath the watchful eyes of the lanista’s guards. The sun caught dust motes in the air, turning the yard to gold. I blinked against the glare, my stomach twisting in anticipation—not of battle, but of the endless drills to come. We trained beneath the shade of a canvas awning, the sand beneath our feet already warm. The ludus stank of old wounds and oil, mingled with the sweet, rotting perfume of figs from the market next door. In the distance, the Colosseum’s white stone glared from across the city, promise and threat in equal measure. Our instructor, a retired secutor with a drooping eye, barked commands. We formed ranks, wooden swords in hand, and mimed the deadly dance that kept us alive. The sica was not for show. Its curve lent itself to feints and sudden reversals, to darting in close where a larger man’s reach counted for nothing. I moved through the forms, sweat streaking my brow, aware of the eyes upon me. There were always visitors—senators’ sons, bored matrons, even the odd nobleman come to wager on our fates. We were entertainment and investment both. Some days, I felt more animal than man. During a break, I leaned against the shade of the wall, cradling my sica. The blade was pitted from years of use, its edge keen. My thumb found the notch where I had carved a mark for every match survived. Twenty-seven notches. The odds grew longer with each fight. Vibius came to stand beside me, his helmet tucked beneath his arm. “You fight tomorrow,” he said, not unkindly. He had lost a brother in the sand, and since then, had softened to the rest of us. “The editor is a senator’s nephew. They say he’s generous with the wooden sword, if the crowd is pleased.” I shrugged. The wooden sword—rudis—was freedom, the greatest lie in Rome. Few ever earned it, and fewer still survived long enough to enjoy it. Still, it dangled before us, a carved promise. “And if they are not pleased?” He smiled, thin and tired. “Then you die well, Siro. That is all that matters.” A slave boy brought us watered wine in battered cups. I drank, savoring the coolness. Over the courtyard wall, I glimpsed the city in motion: women haggling over fish, children in rags chasing stray dogs, a pair of soldiers lounging in the shade, laughing. The world spun on, indifferent to our fates. I thought of the emperor—Commodus, they whispered, fancied himself a gladiator, a god in flesh. In the baths, men talked of grain shortages, of riots in the Subura, of the Senate’s plots. But here, in the sand, none of that mattered. The people wanted blood and spectacle. Bread and circuses, they called it. Rome’s answer to hunger and unrest. Yet even here, the city’s troubles pressed in. Food was scarce; we were given barley instead of wheat, the bread coarse and heavy. The guards watched us more closely, wary of rebellion. Once, I had hoped for a slave’s revolt, the kind told in whispers about Spartacus. Now, I saw only tired men, broken by hope. Still, there were moments—small and sharp as my sica—when I remembered I was alive. The taste of fresh water, the laughter of a friend, the hush that fell when the crowds roared your name. I was Siro, the Scourge of the North. I was a killer, a slave, a story told in blood and sand. That night, as the city quieted, I sat in my cell and sharpened my blade. The moon rose over Rome, silvering the rooftops, the great temples and shrines. Somewhere, the emperor feasted. Somewhere, a mother wept for a lost son. And I, weapon in hand, waited for another day. The sica gleamed in the lamplight, curved like memory. This blade was all I had—my past, my future, the thin line between death and survival. Tomorrow, I would step into the arena. But tonight, I listened to the city’s heart, and dreamed of home.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This historical fiction piece effectively transports us to ancient Rome through the eyes of a Dacian gladiator named Siro. The writing demonstrates strong attention to sensory details, creating a vivid atmosphere of the ludus (gladiator training school) with descriptions of smells, sounds, and sights that ground the reader in the setting. The author skillfully weaves in historical context about Emperor Commodus, the social hierarchy within the gladiatorial ranks, and the "bread and circuses" approach to maintaining social order. The protagonist is well-developed through his internal monologue, revealing his Dacian origins, his relationship with his weapon (the sica), and his resigned attitude toward his fate. The curved blade serves as both a physical tool and a metaphorical connection to his homeland, effectively symbolizing his identity as an outsider within Roman society. The prose is generally strong, with evocative phrases like "the sun caught dust motes in the air, turning the yard to gold" and "I was a killer, a slave, a story told in blood and sand." The author maintains a consistent melancholic tone throughout, capturing the protagonist's stoic acceptance of his circumstances while still allowing glimpses of his humanity. The piece successfully avoids combat scenes as instructed, instead focusing on training, interactions with fellow gladiators, and quiet moments of reflection. The political and social context is subtly integrated through references to grain shortages, Senate plots, and the emperor's excesses, showing how these larger issues affect even those at society's margins. There are a few instances where the prose becomes slightly purple, with metaphors occasionally feeling forced. Some descriptions, like "curved and hungry as a crescent moon" for the sica, verge on cliché. The piece could benefit from more specific historical details about gladiatorial life to further authenticate the setting. The ending effectively brings the narrative full circle, returning to the image of the sica and the protagonist's dual identity as both captive and survivor. While not particularly surprising, the conclusion feels appropriate to the reflective nature of the piece. Overall, this is a strong example of historical fiction that successfully creates an immersive glimpse into Roman gladiatorial life while exploring the protagonist's inner world and connecting his personal experience to broader societal issues. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Epistolary: The Lighthouse Keeper — Score: 80.0
Prompt:
The Lighthouse Keeper Epistolary Narrative: Write a story told entirely through a series of brief correspondences: telegrams or letters or emails between two characters. The correspondence should span several months or years, and reveal a gradually unfolding plot. Use distinct voices for each character, and include details that provide insight into their personalities and motivations. The story should build to an emotional climax, and the final letter should provide a satisfying resolution. The setting is a lighthouse keeper writing to his mother. He is working class and Scottish. He is struggling with the isolation of his posting. Write naturally and without cliches. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**The Lighthouse Keeper** --- **Letter from: Angus McKinnon, Eilean Mor Lighthouse** **To: Mrs. Elspeth McKinnon, 14 Rosebank Crescent, Glasgow** **3rd March 1957** Ma, I’ve arrived. They brought me over in a trawler, wind biting like a dog. The tower’s sound as a bell, though the paint’s flaking. The sea’s everywhere, loud and close. Mr. Dalziel, the head keeper, is a dour man—barely said three words and two of them were “aye.” I’ve my own room, small but warm, and a view east to the rocks. The gulls are worse than the city pigeons, cheeky brutes. I’ve hung the brass compass Grandad gave me on the wall. Thought of you as I unpacked. Don’t worry. I’ll write every Sunday. Your son, Angus --- **Letter from: Mrs. Elspeth McKinnon, Glasgow** **To: Angus McKinnon, Eilean Mor Lighthouse** **7th March 1957** Dearest Angus, Glad to hear you arrived safe. I can picture you with your stubborn chin set against the wind. Watch yourself on those rocks, and don’t let that Dalziel browbeat you. I’ve set your room just as you left it—still smells of boot polish. The neighbors ask after you. Mrs. Cairns sent over a jar of her bramble jam for you—though I’ll wager the gulls will get it before you do. Tell me if you’re eating well, and if the bed is comfortable. I worry for your sleep. Love, Ma --- **Letter from: Angus** **14th March 1957** Ma, Food’s fine, except Dalziel boils everything. I sneak some oats for porridge, remind me of home. Nights are loud—wind howling, lantern clanging. I mind your stories about the selkies, watching shapes in the spray. Lonely here, truth told. Dalziel keeps to himself, and the assistant, Billy, is a lad younger than me, clumsy as a calf. Miss the city, the rumble of trams. The compass swings when the wind picks up. I keep it near my bunk. It’s old, but the needle’s true—makes me think of Grandad, and you. Angus --- **Letter from: Elspeth** **21st March 1957** Angus, You always were one for the old tales, even if you wouldn’t say so. I expect the sea will teach you patience, as it did your father. I’m glad you’ve the compass. Remember, it’s not just for direction—it’s a bit of your family, come with you. Try to speak to that Billy—he might be as lonesome as you. Stir yourself to kindness. I made your favorite stew last night. Empty chair at the table. All my love, Ma --- **Letter from: Angus** **4th April 1957** Ma, I took your advice. Billy’s daft but eager. We play dominoes in the lantern room. He’s from Aberdeen, misses his sisters, says I remind him of his uncle. Dalziel caught us laughing and glared, but I think he’s less gruff than he lets on—found him humming once, thought I didn’t hear. Storm last night. Lantern nearly blew out. I gripped the compass hard, felt like holding your hand. The sea’s beautiful, Ma, but cruel. Saw a ship’s light far off—made me think of you, waiting for news. I’m trying to be brave. Angus --- **Telegram from: Elspeth** **12th May 1957** ANGUS STOP GLAD YOU’RE MAKING FRIENDS STOP FATHER WOULD BE PROUD STOP REMEMBER TO EAT ENOUGH STOP MISS YOU LOVE MA --- **Letter from: Angus** **25th June 1957** Ma, Billy’s gone—his mum fell ill, so he’s off home. Just me and Dalziel now. Place is quiet as a grave. I keep busy—painting, cleaning the lenses, reading Grandad’s old almanac. Some days the fog’s so thick, I can’t see my own boots. I talk to the compass, daft as it sounds. Pretend it’s you, telling me off for slouching. Got your parcel—jam survived! Shared it with Dalziel, and he smiled, a real one this time. I’m learning to like the silence, but sometimes it presses on me. Write soon—your letters are a lantern in the dark. Angus --- **Letter from: Elspeth** **2nd July 1957** Angus, You always were stubborn. I’m proud of you, more than you know. I keep your letters in a box by the window, read them when the city noise gets too much. I worry about your loneliness, but I know you’ll find your own peace. Tell Dalziel thanks for watching over you, even if it’s silent-like. The compass was your grandfather’s when he worked the river tugs. He’d want you to have it, to remember where you come from. I’m well, don’t fret. The garden’s blooming, and the neighbors still ask for you. Love, Ma --- **Letter from: Angus** **17th August 1957** Ma, I’m coming home next month, just for a week. Dalziel’s niece is to be married, so I’ve leave at last. I’ll bring the compass, I want to show you how polished it is now. I’ll sit at the table, eat your stew, and tell you all about the wild sea and the storm. I miss you, Ma. The lighthouse is grand and lonely, but the light inside’s just as important as the one on the tower. Soon, Angus --- **Letter from: Elspeth** **21st August 1957** Angus, My heart is full. The stewpot is ready, your bed is turned down. I’ll polish the silver and set out Grandad’s old photos. Come home safe. The city’s not the same without your boots on the stair. The compass will always point you home, so long as you carry us with you. All my love, Ma
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This epistolary narrative effectively captures the relationship between a lighthouse keeper and his mother through their correspondence. The piece successfully establishes the isolated setting of Eilean Mor Lighthouse and develops the character of Angus McKinnon, a working-class Scottish man struggling with loneliness. The letters reveal character development through subtle details rather than explicit statements. Angus gradually adapts to his isolated posting, moving from initial discomfort to finding meaning in his work and relationships. The mother's character is well-established through her nurturing tone and practical concerns. The Scottish working-class voice is maintained consistently, with authentic but not overdone dialect markers. Phrases like "dour man," "cheeky brutes," and "mind your stories" provide cultural authenticity without resorting to stereotypical Scottish expressions. The narrative effectively builds an emotional arc through the correspondence. We see Angus's initial discomfort, his growing connection with Billy and eventually Dalziel, and his evolving relationship with isolation. The compass serves as an effective symbol throughout, representing family connection and guidance. The prose is generally clean and effective, avoiding purple passages while still providing evocative descriptions of the lighthouse environment. The writer uses sensory details well: "wind biting like a dog," "the sea's everywhere, loud and close," and "nights are loud—wind howling, lantern clanging." However, there are some weaknesses. The emotional climax feels somewhat understated—Angus's announcement that he's coming home doesn't carry the weight it might. The resolution, while satisfying in its warmth, doesn't fully capitalize on the emotional potential built throughout the piece. Additionally, while the characters are distinct, they could be more deeply developed through more specific details about their pasts and personalities. The format shifts slightly with the inclusion of a telegram, which adds variety but isn't fully exploited as a different communication medium—it reads much like the letters, just shorter. The narrative successfully spans several months as requested, though the passage of time could be more clearly marked in some transitions. The distinct voices for mother and son are maintained consistently, though they could be further differentiated. Overall, this is a competent and often touching epistolary narrative that effectively captures the relationship between mother and son against the backdrop of lighthouse isolation. It succeeds in creating an emotional connection while avoiding sentimentality. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 14.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 5.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Hacker Mindset — Score: 79.3
Prompt:
Hacker Mindset Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a reformed (now) white hat hacker who cannot help but notice exploitable weaknesses in both systems and people they encounter. They habitually look for vulnerabilities and exploit vectors. The narrative takes place during a first date at a restaurant, where they're trying to focus on human connection. It's going surprisingly well due to a discovered shared nerd-fandom (magic the gathering). Things go a little sideways when the date reveals a noticeably insecure phone unlock pattern, which protagonist can't help but comment on. They are then left to negotiate the fallout of this faux pas and attempt to salvage (or perhaps sabotage) the remainder of the date. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The hostess hands us a menu. I try to focus on her—my date, not the hostess, though her badge is a cheap sticker that could be peeled and swapped in seconds, and I’m already clocking the WiFi password taped to the counter: **PastaLover123**. I resist the urge to check if the “1” is a one or a lowercase “L.” Old habits, sharp as ever. She’s nervous, but not fidgety. That’s good. I’m nervous, but hiding it with practiced composure. She laughs when I mention the time I lost a full set of dual lands to a turn-three combo, and I feel my shoulders loosen. I can do this—I can be normal. Or at least pass for it. She’s telling me about her favorite set—Innistrad—and her eyes light up with the kind of glee I used to reserve for a fresh zero-day exploit. I ask just the right questions, drop a joke about “counterspells in real life,” and she actually snorts. I feel like I’m winning, which is a different but not unwelcome sensation. I let my eyes drift—habit, again. The couple at the next table has left their phone on the edge, screen up. Notifications bloom across the lock screen; no PIN, just swipe. The register is old, running Windows XP. The server’s POS badge is attached with a rusty clip. I clock all of it and try not to smile at the absurdity. I’m not here to break things anymore. She excuses herself to the restroom. I catch the host plugging his phone into a charger at the bar—USB exposed, trustingly waiting for a “juice jacking” attack. I stare at my water as if it’ll drown these thoughts. Back at the table, she unlocks her phone to show me a meme. It’s a simple unlock pattern—bottom left, up, across, down. Barely three moves. I see the grease trail from her finger, the faint smudge map that would make it trivial for even a bored waiter to reconstruct. My brain is already running through attack vectors: shoulder surfing, social engineering, a bit of dusting powder. I want to let it go. “Be normal,” I tell myself. “Be a person. Not a scanner. Not a threat modeler.” But the words slip out, unbidden. “You know, that’s a pretty weak unlock pattern.” She freezes, thumb hovering mid-air. Her eyes narrow. The moment cracks, the vibe shifts—just a little, but enough for me to feel it like a fault line under the table. “Excuse me?” I scramble. “Sorry, I—I do security for a living. I just… notice stuff.” She’s still looking at me, not quite angry, more… wary. Like she’s not sure whether to laugh it off or recoil. “Are you one of those people who go around hacking their friends’ phones?” “No, no, not anymore. I mean, not ever, really, not like that. I used to do some… less-than-ethical stuff, but I’m white hat now. Promise.” My hands are sweating. I want to reach for my drink, but that would expose my own unlock method. I leave my phone in my pocket. She’s silent for a moment. The air feels static, like a room full of unpatched routers. I think of all the times I’ve been here before—the split second when someone realizes you don’t quite see the world the way they do. That you’re always mapping, always calculating risks, always a half-step out of sync. She glances down at her phone, then back at me. “So, what else do you see when you look at people? Just—vulnerabilities?” I want to say no. I want to say I see their strengths, their quirks, their kindness. But the truth is, I see everything—the cracks and the seams, the default passwords and the social tells. I see how easily systems fail, how humans are just as hackable as any network. I shrug, awkward. “Sorry. It’s just a reflex. I try not to… make it weird.” She laughs, but it’s a little brittle. “Well, congratulations. Now I feel like I have to change my whole life.” A part of me wants to backpedal, to offer technical advice, to tell her about password managers and two-factor authentication. Another part of me wants to lean in and admit I’m just scared—that the only way I know how to connect is by understanding what could go wrong. Instead, I try honesty. “I get that a lot. I know it sounds… intense. But I promise, I’m not judging. I just want people to be safe. It’s like—if you saw someone about to step in a pothole, you’d warn them, right?” She considers. “I guess. But you don’t have to point out every pothole.” Fair. I nod, and for a moment, we sit in silence. The restaurant hums around us: someone at the bar typing the WiFi password into their phone, the host collecting empty glasses. **PastaLover123**. I wonder how many people here reuse passwords, how many have Bluetooth turned on, how many have just trusted that their data is safe in a place like this. I take a breath. “Okay. No more unsolicited advice. Scout’s honor.” She smiles, just a little. “Deal. But if you see me about to get phished, you have to tell me.” “Only if you’re about to fall for it,” I agree. The tension eases, the conversation finds a new rhythm. We talk about deck building, favorite commanders, the agony of missing a land drop. I catch myself enjoying it. But the scanner in my brain never really shuts off. I notice the waitress’s ID badge, the open USB port, the password taped to the counter. I catalog, record, file away. I think maybe that’s just how I’m wired. But tonight, I let the vulnerabilities be. Tonight, I try to see the person in front of me, not just the attack surface. She’s telling a story about a pre-release tournament when her phone buzzes again. She unlocks it—same pattern—but she catches my eye and winks. “Don’t say it.” I grin. This time, I don’t. Maybe that’s progress. Maybe, just for tonight, I can be more than my flaws. Maybe, just for tonight, I can patch things up as I go.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative effectively captures the mindset of a reformed white hat hacker on a first date. The protagonist's internal monologue reveals their constant scanning for vulnerabilities—from the restaurant's WiFi password to their date's phone unlock pattern—while trying to focus on human connection. The piece excels at maintaining a consistent voice throughout. The narrator's technical perspective colors everything they observe, creating an authentic portrayal of someone who can't turn off their security-minded thinking. Lines like "I see the grease trail from her finger, the faint smudge map that would make it trivial for even a bored waiter to reconstruct" demonstrate how the character's specialized knowledge affects their worldview. The narrative follows the prompt's requirements closely, depicting the shared interest in Magic: The Gathering, the faux pas regarding the phone unlock pattern, and the subsequent attempt to salvage the date. The internal monologue format is maintained throughout, with minimal external dialogue that serves to punctuate key moments. The character development is nuanced, showing the protagonist's self-awareness about their habits and their genuine desire to connect despite their security-focused mindset. The date character is also given dimension through her reactions and willingness to understand the protagonist's perspective. The prose flows naturally with a good balance of technical observations and emotional reflection. Metaphors like "The air feels static, like a room full of unpatched routers" effectively blend the character's technical knowledge with their emotional state. However, the piece could be stronger in a few areas. While the imagery is generally good, some descriptions feel somewhat generic. The resolution comes a bit too easily, with the date quickly moving past what could have been a more significant breach of social etiquette. This makes the ending feel slightly incongruent with the tension built earlier. The protagonist's transformation from anxious scanner to someone who can "patch things up" feels a bit rushed and not fully earned within the constraints of the narrative. Despite these minor issues, the piece successfully creates an engaging character study that balances technical details with human connection. The reader gets a clear sense of the protagonist's internal struggle and their attempt to navigate a social situation while battling their ingrained habits. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 7 Unearned Transformations: 8 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 14 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 15.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 7.0, Unearned Transformations: 8.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 14.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Overthinking It — Score: 90.2
Prompt:
Overthinking It Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on a classmate. The narrative takes place during a group science project where they're paired together, as she cycles through rehearsed conversations while second-guessing each potential approach. Her inner thoughts should reveal the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud, her fears of coming across as desperate or weird, and the exhausting process of monitoring her every word, expression, and movement for potential embarrassment. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The smell hits me first—the ammonia, sharp and sour, not quite masking the other smells of middle school: pencil shavings, rubber bands, and the faint, ever-present ghost of cafeteria pizza. I almost forget why I’m here, standing at Lab Table Four with my hands curled around the edge. Lila and Marcus are at the next table, already arguing about the data. But I’m not with them. I’m with *him*. Ryan is reading the worksheet, lips moving silently. His hair falls over one eyebrow. I know, absolutely, that if I open my mouth, something weird will come out. Something like, “Did you know ammonia has been used as a cleaning agent since ancient Egypt?” Or, “I think the smell of ammonia is kind of… interesting?” I can already hear myself saying it—too eager, too random, too *me*. Don’t say anything yet. Think it through. Think of something normal. He glances over. “Um, do you want to start with the first experiment?” His voice is normal. Casual. How do people just do that? How do words come out so easy for them? I nod, maybe too quickly. “Yeah. Sure.” The word comes out like a squeak, and I swallow hard, cheeks burning. Did he notice? He probably noticed. He’s probably thinking, “Wow, she’s weird.” Or, “Why did I get stuck with her?” Okay. Reset. I can do this. We’re supposed to test the pH of different solutions. There’s a pipette, a little cup of pinkish cabbage juice, a row of mystery liquids. I could say, “I’ll write down the results if you want to do the drops?” Or is that bossy? Or lazy? Or like I don’t want to do the experiment? Or like I’m trying to get out of work because I’m too nervous to touch the pipette? Which is true but also makes me sound ridiculous. Maybe I should just do the thing. Take initiative. But what if I knock something over? What if I spill the cabbage juice everywhere and everyone looks at me and remembers it for the rest of the year? I picture Ryan’s face: eyebrows up, maybe a little smile, but not the nice kind. The kind he gives to people who mess up their presentations or trip over their own backpacks. He’s already picking up the first test tube, so I grab the worksheet, even though my fingers feel stiff and cold. “Uh, I’ll write,” I say, and my voice cracks on the last word. I wish I could explain, *I’m not always like this in my head*. In my head, I’m funny and smooth and I say things like, “Wow, what’s your hypothesis? I think this one’ll be basic, but I’m willing to bet lunch on it.” In my head, he laughs and says, “You’re on,” and then we talk about science and Star Wars and maybe—someday—other things. But out loud, the words shrink. I’m shrinking, too. He drips the cabbage juice into the first cup. It swirls, turns bright magenta. “Whoa,” he says, grinning. “That’s so cool.” Say something. Say something. “It’s because of anthocyanins,” I blurt. Oh, *great*. “That’s, um, the pigment in the cabbage. It changes color depending on the pH.” I stare at the worksheet, pretending to be fascinated by the lines, but my heart is thudding so hard I can hear it in my ears. Ryan is quiet for half a second. Too long. Now he thinks I’m a know-it-all. Or maybe he thinks I’m showing off. Or maybe he’s bored. Or maybe he’s planning how he’ll tell his friends later, “She went off about anthocyanins for no reason.” But then: “Really? That’s awesome.” He’s looking at me, and his smile is—nice. Not the backpack-tripping kind. “How do you know that?” My brain freezes. I can’t say, “I read the whole science book last summer because I was bored and I like chemistry and also I like you and maybe if I’m good at science you’ll notice me.” So I just say, “Um, I dunno. I just read stuff sometimes.” The air still smells like ammonia. I can taste it now, metallic on my tongue. It makes me want to cough, but I hold it in. Coughing would be another thing for him to notice. “Weird girl, always coughing, always talking about cabbage juice.” I write down “magenta” in tiny, careful letters. Should I say something else? Should I ask him a question? But what if I ask the wrong thing? What if I ask, “Do you like science?” and he says, “No, not really,” and then there’s a silence so huge it swallows me whole? Or what if I ask something too personal, like, “What’s your favorite element?” and he thinks that’s a dumb question and tells everyone I’m obsessed with elements? He’s already moving to the next cup. “Want to do this one?” he asks, holding out the pipette. He’s being nice. He’s trying to include me. That means something, right? Or is he just being polite because he has to? I can’t tell. I can never tell. I take the pipette. My hand shakes a little, but I hope he doesn’t see. The liquid drops in, and it turns greenish-blue. “Neutral, I think,” I say, and it almost sounds normal. My head is buzzing, though. Every movement feels like it’s under a microscope. Am I standing too close? Too far? Does my hair look weird from this angle? Am I breathing loud? Is my shirt stupid? He leans over to see the color, and his shoulder brushes mine. Electricity jolts through me. I freeze. Do I move away? Would that be rude? Would it be weird to just stand here and pretend I didn’t notice? Is he noticing how tense I am? Is he going to think I’m gross? I force myself to write, “blue-green” on the sheet. My handwriting looks shaky. I wish I could just disappear into the paper. We move through the experiment. Every time he speaks, I rehearse three responses in my head, but only ever manage the shortest version out loud. “Yeah.” “Okay.” “That’s cool.” I wish I could show him the real me, the one who loves science, who writes stories in her head, who has a million questions but is too scared to ask. Ammonia stings my nose again. I think about telling him, “I hate this smell,” but what if he likes it? Or what if he thinks I’m just complaining? So I say nothing. When we finish, he grins at me. “We make a pretty good team,” he says. For a second, I almost believe him. For a second, I almost feel like I belong here, at this table, in this moment, together. I smile back, hoping it looks easy. On the inside, it feels like flying. On the outside, I hope it just looks like a smile.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative effectively captures the internal monologue of an 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on her science partner. The piece excels at portraying the protagonist's overthinking process, showing the stark contrast between her articulate internal voice and her stilted external communication. The character's anxiety is palpable through her constant second-guessing and catastrophizing. Lines like "I can already hear myself saying it—too eager, too random, too *me*" reveal her self-consciousness, while moments such as "In my head, I'm funny and smooth" effectively illustrate the gap between her internal and external selves. The narrative successfully conveys how exhausting this constant self-monitoring is for her. The prose is particularly strong in its sensory details. The opening with the ammonia smell grounds us immediately in the science lab setting, and recurring references to this smell help maintain the setting throughout. The physical manifestations of anxiety—"my heart is thudding so hard I can hear it in my ears," "My hand shakes a little"—add authenticity to the character's experience. The narrative maintains a consistent voice throughout, capturing the intelligent yet socially anxious perspective of the protagonist. Her knowledge of chemistry (anthocyanins) demonstrates her intelligence while simultaneously becoming a source of social anxiety, which is a nuanced portrayal. The piece avoids the trap of making Ryan a one-dimensional crush object. His reactions feel natural and kind without being unrealistically perfect. The subtle progression of their interaction feels authentic to middle school dynamics. The ending strikes an appropriate balance—it offers a small moment of connection without resolving all the protagonist's anxiety or suggesting an unrealistic transformation. The line "On the inside, it feels like flying. On the outside, I hope it just looks like a smile" beautifully encapsulates her experience. If there are weaknesses, they're minor. Some readers might want more specific details about the protagonist's broader life or Ryan's character beyond this interaction. The narrative occasionally relies on rhetorical questions to convey anxiety, which becomes slightly repetitive. However, this repetition also effectively mimics the circular nature of anxious thinking. Overall, this is an emotionally resonant piece that captures the internal experience of social anxiety with nuance and authenticity, while maintaining engagement through a well-paced science experiment scenario. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 1 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18

+ First-person unique perspective: Rehearsing Rejection — Score: 87.2
Prompt:
Rehearsing Rejection Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of someone with borderline personality disorder who frequently plays out worst-case scenarios of how friends and loved ones might judge them. They construct elaborate internal dialogues, complete with imagined criticisms and their own defensive responses. The narrative takes place as they prepare to meet a close friend & recent lover, who has been somewhat distant lately, triggering their abandonment fears. Their inner monologue should reveal how they cycle between anticipating rejection, mentally rehearsing confrontations, and developing preemptive resentments as protective measures. Incorporate the *actual* events & interactions that are *not* in fact judgemental or involving rejection (in fact, the opposite), and represent how these are interpreted, how the validation & love is desperately felt & needed -- and then immediately questioned. Capture the cognitive dissonance in this struggle. Include moments where they briefly recognize the pattern but struggle to interrupt it, showing limited (and selective) self awareness, competing with the compelling nature of these imagined scenarios. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I stand in the hallway, hand on the door, staring at my reflection in the mirror. My shoulders hunch in, chin tucked, like I’m bracing for a blow—exactly the posture you’d expect from someone about to get bad news. I try to straighten up, but my body doesn’t quite believe me. I look tired. Defensive. Already rehearsing. Because it’s easier if I can prepare. If I imagine the worst, maybe it won’t hurt so much when it comes. Or maybe I’ll spot it before it happens—catch the rejection in the flicker of an eye, the edge in a voice. Like I can outsmart hurt by expecting it. I picture seeing Riley at the café. Their face is tight, mouth unsmiling. They’re already sitting, arms folded, barely glancing up when I walk in. “Hey,” they say, flat. “You’re late.” I can see myself shrinking, defensive, voice a little too sharp: “It was only five minutes. Traffic was shit.” I know how it goes from there—Riley sighs, looks away, says something like, “It’s always something with you.” I feel the heat in my cheeks, the sting behind my eyes. The urge to say, “If I’m such a burden, why do you even bother?” Maybe I do say it, in the script in my head. I play it all out, the fight, the disappointment, the way they finally say, “I can’t do this anymore.” I tell myself I’m ready for it. But the real Riley—in the real world—texts me before I leave. “Can’t wait to see you. Want anything from the bakery?” I stare at the screen a long time, reading it over and over. My chest loosens, a fraction. They’re thinking about me. They care. I can feel the relief, almost embarrassing in its intensity, like I’ve been holding my breath for days. But then—what if they’re just being polite? What if they feel obligated? I imagine them rolling their eyes after hitting send, thinking, God, I hope she doesn’t make this weird today. I can hear them telling someone later, “I had to see her—she gets so anxious if I don’t.” I picture them sighing, wishing I would just let things go. I rehearse the conversation again, this time with me playing it cool. “Hey, Riley,” casual, breezy, as if I don’t notice the distance. They’ll see I’m not needy, not desperate. If they pull away, I’ll pull away faster. I can be cold too. I can be the one who leaves first. But then, what if they notice I’m distant and think I don’t care? What if they feel rejected, and that’s why they seem off lately? I see myself apologizing—too much, too soon. “Are you mad at me? Did I do something wrong?” I know that’s too much, but the urge is there, crawling up my throat. I wish I could just stop. I wish my brain would quiet down, just for a minute, let me feel the good stuff and believe it’s real. Every time I get close to that—like with the bakery text—it’s like a switch gets flipped. Good things are dangerous. If I trust them, I’m vulnerable. If I need them, they’ll leave. I know, somewhere, that not everyone is waiting to hurt me. That Riley has been kind, patient, funny. That we’ve had whole afternoons where I felt safe, warm, wanted. But it’s like remembering a dream. I can’t hold onto it for more than a second before the doubts start up again. I check my phone again. No new messages. What if they change their mind? What if this is the day they realize I’m too much, too intense, too broken? I feel the familiar resentment start to simmer—if they’re going to leave, I wish they’d just do it already. I wish I didn’t care. I wish I was the kind of person who could just shrug and move on. I try to name it, like my therapist said. “Catastrophizing. Black-and-white thinking.” I say it quietly, but it sounds like someone else’s voice. I know the words. I know the pattern. But it still feels real. The fear still floods in, thick and hot. I walk to the café, heart pounding, rehearsing lines—jokes, excuses, apologies, accusations. I’m ready for anything. I have a script for every possible failure. But Riley is there when I arrive, smiling, waving. They stand to hug me, and I feel the warmth in their arms, the press of their hand on my back. “Hey, you look great,” they say, and I feel a rush of happiness so sharp it almost hurts. I want to believe it. I want to melt into it. But there’s a voice that whispers, *They have to say that. They’re just being nice. You’re making this up.* Riley starts talking about their week, about work, about a movie they saw. They meet my eyes, laugh at my jokes, reach across the table to squeeze my hand. It’s good. It’s easy. For a few minutes, I forget to be afraid. Then I notice them glancing at their phone. Just for a second—maybe checking the time, maybe a message. The fear spikes. *They’re bored. They wish they were somewhere else. They’re only here because they feel sorry for you.* I pull my hand back, fidget with my napkin, go quiet. Riley notices. “Hey, you okay?” Their face is soft, concerned. I want to say yes. I want to say, “I know you care.” Instead I say, “You seem distracted.” I hear the accusation in my voice and hate myself for it. Riley’s face crumples a little. “Sorry, I just got a text from my sister. She’s having a rough day.” Their voice is gentle, reassuring. “I’m here. I want to be here.” I nod, but it feels like a lie. I want to believe it, but the script in my head won’t shut up. I imagine them telling someone later, “She’s so sensitive. I can’t do anything right.” I want to snap at them, push them away, save myself before they can leave. I want to pull them closer, beg them not to go. I do neither. I just sit, silent, pretending I’m fine. We walk home together, arms brushing. Riley slips their hand into mine. For a moment, I let myself believe it’s real, that I’m wanted, safe. I can feel their love, warm and solid. But already the doubts are creeping in. *How long will this last? What if they get tired of me? What if I ruin everything?* I catch my reflection in a shop window—shoulders hunched, eyes darting. I look like someone waiting for something bad to happen. I try to shake it off, squeeze Riley’s hand tighter. I tell myself, *Just be here. Just enjoy this.* I almost manage it. Almost.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative effectively captures the internal experience of someone with borderline personality disorder (BPD), particularly the characteristic pattern of anticipating rejection and mentally rehearsing confrontations. The piece is structured almost entirely as internal monologue, as requested, with the protagonist cycling through various imagined scenarios of rejection while simultaneously experiencing moments of actual connection with Riley. The writing excels at depicting cognitive distortions common in BPD. The protagonist catastrophizes ("I picture seeing Riley at the café. Their face is tight, mouth unsmiling"), engages in black-and-white thinking, and shows hypervigilance to perceived signs of rejection ("Then I notice them glancing at their phone. Just for a second"). The narrative successfully contrasts these distorted perceptions with reality, showing how even positive interactions are immediately questioned and undermined by the protagonist's fears. The piece demonstrates strong psychological insight into the BPD experience. The protagonist shows limited self-awareness ("I try to name it, like my therapist said. 'Catastrophizing. Black-and-white thinking.'") while still being unable to escape the compelling nature of their imagined rejection scenarios. The writing captures the desperate need for validation alongside the immediate questioning of that validation when received. The prose is clean and effective, with natural sentence flow that mimics authentic thought patterns. The imagery is particularly strong in physical descriptions that reflect emotional states: "I stand in the hallway, hand on the door, staring at my reflection in the mirror. My shoulders hunch in, chin tucked, like I'm bracing for a blow." These bodily manifestations of anxiety help ground the narrative and make the character's experience tangible. The ending effectively captures the "almost but not quite" nature of the protagonist's struggle—they can momentarily connect with Riley's genuine affection but cannot fully trust or sustain that connection. This reflects the prompt's request to show the character's struggle to interrupt their negative thought patterns. Where the piece could be stronger is in developing more specific, unique details about the protagonist and Riley's relationship. While the dynamics are well-portrayed, the characters and their history remain somewhat generic. More concrete details about their shared experiences or specific triggers for the protagonist's fears would add depth. Additionally, while the internal monologue is convincing, it occasionally relies on somewhat familiar phrasings about BPD symptoms rather than finding fresh language for these experiences. Overall, this is a psychologically astute, well-executed narrative that effectively fulfills the prompt requirements while creating an emotionally resonant portrayal of BPD's impact on relationships. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Physical-spatial: Blood Debt — Score: 75.0
Prompt:
"Blood Debt" Write a vivid third-person narrative depicting an unsanctioned underground duel between two talented but hot-headed martial artists. Their schools have been embroiled in a generations-old rivalry, and despite strict prohibitions from their masters, these two younger fighters arrange a secret confrontation fueled by personal pride and simmering animosity. - **One fighter** represents **Jigen-ryū**, a traditional, aggressive style practiced historically by elite samurai clans. Its practitioners emphasize explosive offense, decisive strikes, and overwhelming speed. Known historically for their arrogance and disdain toward outsiders, practitioners consider their art superior and untouchable. - **The opposing fighter** employs a form of historical **Piguaquan**, a Chinese martial art traditionally practiced by commoners, bodyguards, and street fighters. This style emphasizes whipping, circular strikes, rapid footwork, unpredictable angles of attack, and evasive maneuvers. Practitioners often come from lower social classes and view the traditional elite as pretentious and detached from true combat effectiveness. The fight takes place in the crumbling ruins of an abandoned temple, now functioning as a hidden arena for illicit duels. Passionate supporters from both factions surround them, wagering money, pride, and reputation on the outcome. **Essential Instructions:** Maintain absolute physical coherence throughout—clearly track fighters' positions relative to each other and their environment. Precisely depict strikes, counters, momentum shifts, and spatial dynamics, allowing readers to clearly visualize the mechanics and choreography of the fight at every moment. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Beneath the fractured moonlight, shattered roof beams cast jagged shadows across the temple ruins. The air reeked of old incense and sweat, thick with the anticipation of the crowd—a ragged ring of partisans, faces blurred by torchlight and fear. Tonight, beneath the gaping maw of a collapsed Buddha, the blood-debt of two schools would be paid. A single step forward, and Katsuragi Ren—Jigen-ryū’s favored scion—set his foot on ancient stone, his crimson-and-black armband gleaming against the sleeve of his white keikogi. He rolled his shoulders, neck cracking, dark eyes narrowed. The hilt of his bokken—hardwood, heavy, lethal—rested against his hip, right hand flexing in readiness. Opposite him, Lin Yao pivoted lightly, the flutter of his sash and armband a bright slash against his faded street jacket. Lin’s hands were empty, fingers loose and flickering, his stance low and coiled, feet shifting across the moss-slick flagstones. A hush rippled through the crowd. The signal—a single, sharp clap—split the silence. Katsuragi moved first, true to his lineage: a blur of white surging forward, bokken slicing a brutal diagonal arc toward Lin’s collarbone. The air hissed as the strike descended. But Lin had already slipped sideways, body folding with boneless grace. His left foot swept behind him, pivoting out of range; his right palm whipped upward, seeking Katsuragi’s exposed ribs. Katsuragi twisted—steel-trap reflexes—letting the palm graze his sleeve as he powered forward, driving his free hand toward Lin’s jaw. Lin ducked, rolling beneath the strike, momentum carrying him behind Katsuragi’s right shoulder. He spun, arm lashing out in a backhand chop aimed at the samurai’s kidney. Katsuragi grunted, dropping low. His bokken crashed down, wood cracking stone where Lin’s ankle had been a heartbeat before. They circled, boots scraping ruins, eyes locked. Curses and cheers erupted from the crowd, echoing between the broken pillars. Snarling, Katsuragi advanced—a barrage of rapid, linear thrusts, each one honed by years of relentless kata. Lin retreated, feet gliding in rapid c-steps, body weaving. The bokken’s tip whistled past his ear, then his jaw, then his floating ribs. Each time, Lin’s torso bent impossibly, his arms snapping in counter-motions—a forearm slap here, a quick wrist flick there—redirecting the wooden blade just enough to buy another precious instant. But Katsuragi’s footwork was inexorable, each step a statement of dominance, herding Lin toward the temple’s northern wall—a jagged edge of collapsed masonry. Two steps more and Lin’s back brushed cold stone. Katsuragi’s lips curled. He feinted left, then lunged, bokken aimed like a spear at Lin’s sternum. Lin, trapped, dropped both hands to the ground, using the wall as an anchor. He spun his body horizontally, legs scissoring through the air in a sweeping arc. Katsuragi’s thrust halted as Lin’s heel caught his forearm, diverting the sword just enough to send it clanging harmlessly against the stone. In a flash, Lin completed the spin, landing on one knee. He shot up, left hand lashing in a whipping chop toward Katsuragi’s exposed throat. Katsuragi barely managed to angle his chin, the chop glancing off his collarbone. He retaliated, driving his shoulder into Lin’s chest, bulldozing him backward into the ring. The crowd roared as Lin staggered, boots skidding against ancient grit. Both men reset—breathing hard, sweat beading their brows. Their armbands, bright and defiant, glimmered in the firelight. Katsuragi pressed his advantage, launching an overhead strike meant to split Lin’s guard. Lin’s arms rose in a crossing block—Piguaquan’s signature “cloud hands”—absorbing the shock, then redirecting the bokken outward with a spiral of his wrists. The weapon’s tip glanced off Lin’s shoulder, tearing cloth but drawing no blood. Katsuragi, undeterred, spun on his heel, unleashing a spinning backfist with his free hand. Lin sidestepped—barely—catching the blow across his cheekbone. Blood blossomed, a thin line under his eye. Lin’s eyes blazed. He sidestepped again, this time inside Katsuragi’s guard, and whipped his right arm in a low, circular strike, hand rigid as a chopping blade. It thudded against Katsuragi’s ribcage, making the Jigen-ryū prodigy grunt and stagger. Sensing an opening, Lin advanced with a blur of circular strikes—wrists, elbows, palms—each one snapping and recoiling, seeking gaps in the samurai’s defense. Katsuragi retreated, blocking high, then low, countering with lightning-fast jabs of the bokken. One glanced off Lin’s forearm; another struck his thigh. Lin grimaced, but pressed on, footwork darting unpredictably—sometimes closing, sometimes retreating, always at an angle. Suddenly, Lin lunged diagonally, spinning low. His leg swept out, aiming to hook Katsuragi’s forward ankle. Katsuragi leaped, twisting in midair, and brought the bokken down in a savage hammer strike. Lin rolled away, but too late—the wooden blade crashed against his shoulder, sending a jolt through his body. The crowd shrieked, half in triumph, half in dread. But Lin, battered, was not broken. He bounced back, using the ruined altar as cover. Katsuragi followed, relentless, driving Lin around the crumbling dais in a deadly waltz. Lin ducked under a horizontal slash, then jumped atop a toppled column, gaining elevation. From this perch, he launched a flying crescent kick—Piguaquan’s unorthodox answer to samurai aggression. Katsuragi sidestepped, but Lin’s heel grazed his temple, making him stumble. Lin landed, spinning instantly into a series of whipping backfists and open-palm strikes, arms blurring in the torchlight. Katsuragi absorbed the blows on his forearms, but the relentless circularity of Lin’s assault began to break through. A palm to the sternum; a knuckle to the solar plexus; a knife-hand across the brow. Roaring, Katsuragi unleashed a final, all-or-nothing charge. He closed the distance in a heartbeat—bokken raised for a killing blow. But Lin, battered and breathless, ducked beneath the arc, twisted behind Katsuragi’s back, and wrapped his arm around the samurai’s throat. In a seamless motion, Lin wrenched Katsuragi off balance, spinning him to the ground. The bokken skittered away, clattering against the stone. Lin straddled Katsuragi, right palm poised above his throat, breath ragged, eyes wild. Blood from brow and cheek mingled on his chin. The crowd was silent—every wager, every grudge, suspended in the charged air between victor and vanquished. Lin’s palm hovered, then withdrew. He rose, chest heaving, and extended a hand to his foe. Tonight, in the ruins, blood had been spilled—but not life. Both men, scarred yet standing, had delivered their schools’ legacy into the uncertain hands of fate.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This narrative successfully depicts an underground martial arts duel between practitioners of Jigen-ryū and Piguaquan, capturing the physical dynamics and technical aspects of the fight with impressive clarity. The author demonstrates strong knowledge of both martial arts styles, accurately representing Jigen-ryū's aggressive, linear attacks and Piguaquan's circular, whipping movements. The physical choreography is the standout element of this piece. The author meticulously tracks the fighters' positions, maintaining spatial coherence throughout the battle. Each movement flows logically from the previous one, allowing readers to visualize the fight sequence clearly. The description of Lin using the wall as an anchor to execute a horizontal spin when cornered is particularly well-executed, demonstrating how the environment factors into the combat. The prose effectively establishes atmosphere through sensory details like "the air reeked of old incense and sweat" and visual elements like "fractured moonlight" and "jagged shadows." The setting—an abandoned temple with collapsed roof beams and a broken Buddha statue—creates an appropriately atmospheric backdrop for this illicit duel. However, the character development is somewhat thin. While we get physical descriptions and fighting styles, we learn little about the fighters' personal motivations beyond a brief mention of "blood-debt." The generations-old rivalry between schools is referenced but not explored in depth. The characters remain somewhat archetypal rather than fully realized individuals with complex emotions. The ending, where Lin shows mercy by withdrawing his palm rather than delivering a final blow, introduces a moral dimension that feels slightly underdeveloped given the limited character work. While it creates a satisfying conclusion to the physical conflict, the emotional stakes aren't fully earned. The prose occasionally verges on purple, with phrases like "beneath the gaping maw of a collapsed Buddha" and "the blood-debt of two schools would be paid." Some metaphors work well, while others feel slightly overwrought. The writing is generally strong but occasionally sacrifices naturalness for dramatic effect. Overall, this is a technically impressive piece that excels at depicting physical combat with clarity and dynamism. It fulfills the core requirement of maintaining physical coherence throughout the fight sequence. Where it falls short is in developing the characters' inner lives and the emotional dimensions of their conflict beyond the physical confrontation. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 12 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Emotionally Complex: 11 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 7 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 4 Unearned Transformations: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 14 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 12.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 14.0, Emotionally Complex: 11.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 5.0, Purple Prose: 7.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 4.0, Unearned Transformations: 6.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 14.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Physical-spatial: Breaking Formation — Score: 88.2
Prompt:
**"Breaking Formation"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a street dancer from a rough neighborhood who's won a scholarship to an elite K-pop training academy in Seoul. Desperately out of place culturally and technically, they struggle with a militaristically precise choreography that contradicts everything about their improvisational background. The punishing rehearsal takes place under a famous instructor known for breaking students to remake them, who sees potential in the narrator's raw talent but not their attitude. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—each dance move, position shift, and spatial relationship must be tracked with precision throughout the studio. Paint an exceptionally vivid kinetic picture through descriptions that capture not just movement but the contrast between the narrator's fluid, expressive style and the mechanical precision demanded. Their internal monologue should reveal culture shock, class anxiety, and the threatening realization that success here might mean losing their authentic movement voice. Include technical terminology that highlights the collision of street and commercial styles, moments when muscle memory betrays them, and a crucial decision point about whether to conform or rebel. Physical clarity is essential—readers must be able to visualize exactly how bodies move through space, how rhythms align or clash, and how the protagonist's body struggles against unfamiliar discipline. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The mirrors in Studio 5 are too clean. I can see every pore, every fleck of sweat already starting to sting my eyes. I’m front row, left side, right near the instructor’s glare—my spot assigned after last week’s “correction.” In the reflection, I’m barely visible, half-shadowed by the overdressed, all-knees-and-elbows trainees in matching black joggers. My own pants are gray, frayed at the cuff, a mark before I even move. “From the top!” Ms. Lee’s voice cuts through the speakers’ beat. The walls pulse with a synth track I’ve heard a thousand times now, but never like this—never this loud, never this rigid. The bass hits in perfect four-counts, no swing, no room for flavor. I plant my feet—right at the tape line, heels together, toes splayed at exactly forty-five degrees. Everyone else pops into first position like it’s muscle memory. For me, it’s a borrowed costume. My toes want to point out, knees loose, ready to bounce, to catch the rhythm and ride it, not break it into pieces. “One! Two! Three! Four!” Ms. Lee’s clap is sharp, ahead of the beat. We launch the routine: right arm snaps up—high V, fingers splayed, palm out. My shoulder stiffens in protest, aching to drop into a looser pop, to let the joint roll. Instead, I force the angle, triceps burning, elbow locked. We step left, feet in parallel, knees snapping straight on the downbeat. In my old crew, we’d hit a glide here, sliding low, letting gravity pull us into the pocket. Here, the step is military: heel down, toe up, hips square, no bounce. My chest wants to lead, to puff out and take space, but the choreography demands the opposite—a sucked-in core, ribs closed, chin up. The mirror shows me a stranger: tight-jawed, back too straight, hands robotic. Downbeat. “Dwi!” Ms. Lee counts in Korean, and I stumble—my brain snags on the language switch. We pivot ninety degrees left, opening into a precise diagonal. My right arm is half a beat late, flailing for the sharp X-cross. Next to me, Minjae’s arm slices the air like a blade—perfect geometry, no wasted motion. He glances, a flicker of annoyance. I’m the ragged note in their chord. We hit the chorus—here’s where the moves should roll, flow, let me breathe. Instead, it’s a rapid-fire sequence: left foot crosses behind, right knee pops up, both hands form a diamond over the face. I lag, my left foot dragging, ankle rolling out to catch balance the way I would in a freestyle set. My body wants to ride the groove, to let my torso snake with the bass. Here, the counts are merciless: every limb has its place, every angle its policing. “Stop!” Ms. Lee’s hand slaps the wall. The music halts mid-bar. “You—again.” Her finger points, not at the group, but straight at me. “Your transitions are lazy. You drag your feet. Why?” English, but clipped. I want to say: because in my world, drag is flavor. Because in the projects, we hit the floor with weight, let the ground talk back. Here, the floor is just a reference, something you tap and leave behind. My jaw works, but nothing comes out. My chest is heaving for a different reason now. “Again. Just you. Five, six, seven, eight.” Alone. I reset—back to first position, toes trembling. The music blares. I force the arm up, lock the elbow, step left, pivot, X-cross. Each move is a battle: my back screaming for the curve, my hips clenching to keep from rolling. The diamond over my face is shaky, fingers spread too far apart. I catch my eyes in the mirror—scared, desperate. Not me. “Stop.” Ms. Lee steps closer, her face unreadable. “You have power. But you refuse to control it. Street is chaos. Here, you must make chaos obey.” I want to scream: chaos is my language. I survived with it. But all I do is nod, swallowing the burn. She walks behind me, places two fingers on my scapula, pressing my shoulders down. “Again. This time, breathe on the up, exhale on the down. Do not improvise.” I try. I really do. I count the beats, force my breathing into rhythm—inhale, exhale. The moves are cleaner, less wild. But I can feel my own style dying, like water forced through a funnel, stripped of its curves and waves. The others are watching. Their faces are masks—polite, distant. Even Minjae, who’s been here since he was twelve, looks somewhere past me, not wanting to see my failure. We group up again, this time in staggered lines—Ms. Lee corrects our spacing by centimeters. My left foot is half a shoe off the tape. She nudges it with a toe. I flush, shrink into the mark, my body folding in on itself. Music. Full out. The routine is a blur: right arm, step, pivot, X-cross, diamond, drop to the floor—palms flat, knees bent, a move that should be a windmill but is now a static pose. I’m fighting my own instincts, muscles twitching to add a slide, a pop, a tiny head nod. I bite down on it, force myself into the grid. Halfway through, muscle memory betrays me. On the cross-step, my left foot glides, ankle rolling, a micro-glide—barely there, but enough. Ms. Lee’s eyes narrow. She saw. I feel panic, shame, and something else—defiance. As we land the final pose—right knee down, left leg extended, arms overhead in a perfect Y—I make a choice. For a split second, I let my wrist flick, shoulder roll, a ghost of home. The movement is subtle, buried in the shape, but it’s there. The song ends. The speakers hiss. Ms. Lee’s silence is heavy, pressing down on all of us. She walks up to me, face unreadable. “Again tomorrow. You must choose: be a street dancer, or be an artist.” I stare at my reflection—sweat-soaked, jaw set. I don’t know if I can surrender everything I am. But I know, for today, I survived. The rhythm in my chest won’t die, not yet.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative effectively captures the physical and cultural clash between street dance and K-pop training. The piece excels in its kinetic descriptions, maintaining physical coherence throughout the dance sequence while highlighting the protagonist's internal struggle. The writing creates a vivid sensory experience through precise descriptions of movement: "right arm snaps up—high V, fingers splayed, palm out." The contrast between the narrator's fluid style and the rigid K-pop choreography is consistently maintained, with technical terminology ("high V," "X-cross," "diamond") that grounds the dance in reality. The physical descriptions are meticulous, allowing readers to visualize the movements clearly. The character's internal conflict is well-developed. We feel their discomfort in this alien environment through observations like "The mirrors in Studio 5 are too clean" and "In the reflection, I'm barely visible." The narrative effectively conveys class anxiety through details like "my own pants are gray, frayed at the cuff" and cultural displacement through the protagonist's struggle with Korean counting. The prose maintains a consistent voice that feels authentic to a street dancer. Short, punchy sentences mirror the staccato rhythm of the choreography, while longer, flowing sentences reflect the narrator's natural style. This technical-stylistic alignment strengthens the thematic content. The piece builds to a meaningful decision point where the protagonist subtly rebels by incorporating their own style: "For a split second, I let my wrist flick, shoulder roll, a ghost of home." This small act of defiance feels earned and resonant with the character's established values. There are some minor weaknesses. The dialogue is minimal but functional. While the instructor's character is somewhat one-dimensional (the strict taskmaster), this serves the purpose of the scene. The ending avoids an overly neat resolution, leaving the protagonist's ultimate choice unresolved but hinting at continued resistance. Overall, this is a strong piece that successfully fulfills the prompt requirements. It maintains physical coherence throughout the dance sequence while developing a compelling character study of someone caught between two worlds, facing the potential loss of their authentic voice. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Gothic-fantasy-humour: Court of the Dreaming — Score: 85.0
Prompt:
Court of the Dreaming: Territorial Dream Dispute. Write a dark fantasy scene with comedic elements set in the Courts of Dream where a case is being heard to determine ownership of a contested dreamscape. Mora, the Slavic nightmare spirit who sits on sleepers' chests causing paralysis and terror, has recently invaded and subverted a carefully crafted recurring dream of a schoolboy, Max. The dream originally featured the boy lying in a field of wildflowers with his crush, always culminating in a muddled almost-kiss and a pleasant confusion of emotions. This dream was the meticulous work of "First Love" (a rosy-cheeked, slightly bashful entity who crafts formative romantic experiences). However, Mora has recently infiltrated the dreamscape, transforming the scene so that when the girl playfully mounts the boy, she morphs into a terrifying yet somehow still confusingly attractive vision who proceeds to sit on his chest and feed on his breath. Mora's defense largely consists of the practical argument that "a girl's gotta eat too, you know?" Write this scene as it unfolds in the courtroom of the Dreaming, with Dream's demeanour, typically impenetrable, betraying a sense of irritation at having to adjudicate such matters. The comedy should derive from the farcical situation, familiar elements of courtroom drama intersecting with the fantastical world of the Dreaming, and the droll portrayal of the characters and their interactions. The humor should be dark and understated throughout. Dream is tempted to some mischief in the resolution of the case. Use descriptives sparingly when setting scene. Write for readability & engagement. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The hourglass loomed at the heart of the Court of the Dreaming, its sands shimmering with the half-remembered stuff of sleep. Its slow drip was the only sound as the Dream Lord presided—pale, impassive, and clearly, unmistakably annoyed. At the plaintiff’s table, the entity known as First Love fidgeted in a sweater vest that seemed to radiate bashfulness. He clutched a battered notebook covered in hearts and trembling with anxious hope. On the opposing bench lounged Mora, the Slavic nightmare spirit, all wild hair, ash-blotched skin, and a predatory smile. She was draped across her chair in a manner that suggested both indolence and the threat of imminent chest-sitting. Dream’s voice rolled out, echoing with centuries of sleeplessness. “Let the record show: this is the matter of Max, age thirteen, versus a disputed dream visitation presently corrupted.” He did not sigh, but the entire room felt as if he wanted to. First Love leapt up. “My Lord Dream, this is a clear violation! For months, I have nurtured Max’s dream—sunlight, wildflowers, the trembling possibility of lips touching—” Mora interrupted with a yawn, showing far too many teeth. “You call that nurturing? The boy was practically choking on hormones. I just gave him something real to sweat about.” Dream’s fingers tapped the arm of his throne, sending ripples across the courtroom’s marble floor. “Mora, your defense?” Mora grinned, her eyes gleaming with the light of a thousand midnight terrors. “A girl’s gotta eat, you know? I only took a tiny nibble. Besides, what’s more formative than a little night panic? Builds character. And strong lungs.” First Love’s blush deepened to the color of a ripe apple. “Max’s dream was never meant to be a… a breathless horror! It should be about confusion, not—well, not *that* kind of confusion!” Mora examined her blackened nails. “He seemed confused enough to me. He couldn’t even scream.” A murmur passed through the gallery—shadowy figures, some sobbing softly into lace handkerchiefs, others scribbling notes with quills shaped like broken hearts. In the back, a phalanx of minor anxieties snickered. Dream’s eyes flicked to the hourglass. “The dream in question: a field, a girl, a first almost-kiss. Then, a transformation—romance to terror, hope to paralysis. Both claim creative rights.” He paused. “How is the boy?” First Love drew himself up. “Max is exhausted, but his grades haven’t slipped. He’s even started writing poetry. Bad poetry, but still—” Mora interjected, “His heart races like a hunted rabbit’s. I’m proud. And he’s stopped leaving his window open at night. Sensible!” Dream’s lips twitched. “The Court will see the contested dream.” With a gesture, the scene unfolded overhead: wildflowers, sunlight, the girl’s shy smile. Then, as she leaned in, her features melted into Mora’s grinning visage, all sharp teeth and hungry eyes. Max, caught halfway between longing and terror, found himself pinned, breathless, in a place where desire and dread were indistinguishable. First Love groaned. “She’s ruined the color palette. It was all warm pastels. Now it’s… who puts mildew in a dream-flower?” Mora gave a theatrical shrug. “I like a little fungus. It’s earthy.” Dream steepled his fingers. “First Love, your closing statement?” First Love rose, clutching his notebook to his chest. “My Lord, the boy deserves gentle confusion—a soft melancholy, not the terror of suffocation. Let him dream of first love, not first apnea.” Dream inclined his head. “Mora?” Mora stretched, her shadow lengthening grotesquely. “You say terror, I say seasoning. Besides, it’s not like you’re starving, Love. There are legions of schoolchildren for you to mess with. Let me have this one. He’s deliciously susceptible.” A pause. One of the minor anxieties sneezed. Dream’s gaze fell on the hourglass, now half-spent. He considered, then spoke with the gravity of one who has seen a million such disputes and will see a million more. “The Court notes both parties’—ah—artistry. Childhood dreams must balance delight and dread. Both have a claim.” First Love’s eyes widened. Mora’s grin faltered. Dream continued, “Therefore: on alternate nights, the dream shall be as First Love intends—sunlit, hopeful, unresolved.
